headline: US interest rates up by quarter point.
content: The US Federal Reserve raised its target interest rate by a quarter point to 1.5 per cent yesterday, and gave no indication that recent weaker economic data would rein in its intention to tighten monetary policy at a measured pace. The policymaking Federal open market committee noted: "In recent months, output growth has moderated and the pace of improvement in labour market conditions has slowed." In line with Congress testimony of Alan Greenspan, Fed chairman, the statement said: "This softness likely owes importantly to the substantial rise in energy prices. The economy nevertheless appears poised to resume a stronger pace of expansion." The rest of the statement was unchanged from June's, with the Fed reiterating that, with underlying inflation expected to be relatively low, rates could be moved back towards a more neutral level "at a pace likely to be measured". The rate increase was expected despite weaker economic activity at the end of the second quarter and a weak July jobs report. Some Fed-watchers predicted the central bank would give itself greater flexibility in its guidance following Friday's announcement that US employers added only 32,000 jobs to payrolls in July. The yield on the two-year Treasury note rose 10 basis points to 2.54 per cent following the announcement and the 10-year yield rose 5 basis points to 4.3 per cent. The S&P 500 rose 1 per cent and the dollar strengthened. Futures contracts suggested investors raised the probability of a September rate increase from below 50 to above 70 per cent. The US labour department reported that productivity grew at a 2.9 per cent annual rate in the second quarter in the non-farm business sector, slower than the 3.7 per cent in the first quarter but above consensus expectations of a 2 per cent rate. Markets, Page 42 www.ft.com/lex

headline: MARKETS REPORT - FED RAISES DISCOUNT RATE.
content: The US Federal Reserve yesterday announced a 50 basis-point increase in the discount rate to 4% from 3.5%, writes Philip Gawith. The dollar's initial response was favourable, jumping from DM 1.5515 before the announcement to DM 1.5660 against the D-Mark. Traders reported a surge of interest in US Treasury bonds, which should help the dollar. New York trading finished with the US currency at DM 1.5615. The decision by the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Fed, was favourably received by analysts, who described it as a 'healthy, decisive move'. The rate increase was the fifth this year by the Fed. It said in a statement that it expected its actions 'to be sufficient, at least for a time, to meet the objective of sustained non-inflationary growth'. The Federal Funds rate - the benchmark for US short-term rates - will rise to 4.75% from 4.25%. Ahead of the FOMC's announcement, which came at 17.17 GMT, currency trading across the board was fairly listless, with volumes low and currencies moving in fairly narrow ranges. The D-Mark was slightly easier as some investors took profits, anticipating a rise in US rates. Sterling had an uneventful day, with the trade weighted index unchanged all day at 78.8. Analysts welcomed both the extent of the Fed's move and the rhetoric accompanying it. Mr Tim Stewart, currency strategist at Morgan Stanley, commented: 'This goes a long way to instilling credibility in the Fed both in terms of its actions and by its rhetoric.' He said the dollar had been given a good deal of support at the DM 1.55 level. Mr Stewart said the dollar would probably take its cue from the Treasury bond market, where the early outlook was encouraging with signs of foreign investors buying. Mr Stewart added that the Fed would be unlikely to move rates again before its November meeting. He is not predicting a further rise this year. But Mr Julian Jessop, international economist at Midland Global Markets, predicted that the Fed Funds rate would probably rise to 5% this year, still a long way short of the 5.85% being discounted by the December Eurodollar contract. Ahead of the FOMC, activity in the interest rate futures markets was subdued. The December short sterling contract traded only 13,400 lots, but closed four basis points firmer at 93.23, helped by a lower than expected July public sector borrowing figure, and the CBI distributive trades survey showing that consumer spending remains patchy. Mr Nick Parsons, treasury economist at CIBC in London, said the market was still 'far too gloomy' about the outlook for rates. He noted that at the beginning of the year, December short sterling reflected three-month interest rates at 4.4% by the end of 1994. This figure is now close to 6.8% - 'a massive turnaround by any standards'. Mr Parsons noted that, going back to 1989, three-month LIBOR, as implied from the futures market, had never closed more than 82 basis points above the base rate. But even if UK rates jump by 3/4 percentage point to 6%, the December contract is still nearly 80 basis points above this level. 'It is hard to see what will drive three-month rates to 6.8% by December,' said Mr Parsons. Ms Liz Ward, economist at Bank Julius Baer in London, makes a similar point, noting that on the March 1995 futures contract for sterling and D-Mark rates, the expected differential has widened from a low of 52 basis points in March to around 200 basis points now. Ms Ward said that while expectations of higher UK short-term rates should have boosted the pound, the reverse has occurred. 'The widening gap seems to have reflected market perceptions of a weaker pound ahead. The causation is flowing from the currency to interest rates, rather than vice versa.' She cited two other factors which explain the 6% fall in the pound against the D-Mark this year. One is that sterling has traded like a 'transatlantic' currency, following roughly half of the 6.7% move down in the dollar. The other is that 'exchange markets have ignored strong UK fundamentals for even stronger ones in Germany'. There also appears to be a belief that the German recovery is less likely than the UK one to foster inflation. Although purchasing power parity estimates suggest the pound is nearly 10% undervalued against the D-Mark, Ms Ward said it is difficult to make a case for buying pounds 'without a convincing move on base rates first'. Sterling finished at DM 2.3951 from DM 2.4061 and at $1.5401 from $1.5467. The Bank of England did not operate in the morning or afternoon rounds yesterday, providing UK money markets with only #90m late assistance after earlier forecasting a #350m shortage. Overnight money traded between 4 1/4 and 6 1/2%. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1994.

headline: FED 'STAYS WITH THE CURVE' ON INFLATION.
content: But critics fear the interest rate increases might hamper economic growth, writes George Graham. The US Federal Reserve's decision yesterday to raise short term interest rates was almost universally expected, but the argument over whether this is the right step to take is not so one-sided. In its statement announcing an increase of half a percentage point in both the discount and federal funds rates, the Fed said it was acting 'against the background of evidence of continuing strength in the economic expansion and high levels of resource utilisation'. 'The actions are intended to keep inflationary pressures contained and thereby foster sustainable economic growth,' the Fed said. But administration officials and Democratic members of Congress are worried that the Fed might be too jittery about prices rises that are still scarcely visible to the naked eye: in its zeal to kill off inflation 18 months down the road, does it not risk killing off an already slowing economic recovery before its time? Mr Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury secretary, and Ms Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, were conciliatory yesterday in their joint statement. 'The administration recognises and respects the independence of the Federal Reserve to make decisions about the nation's monetary policies. We share a common goal with the Federal Reserve of sustained growth with low inflation,' they said. There is not much more the administration can do, except back the Fed's board with new appointees. That seems to be having little effect, for yesterday's vote was unanimous, despite the addition to the board of Mr Alan Blinder and Ms Janet Yellen, two Clinton nominees. Democratic senators were more forthright in their criticism of the Fed's decision. Senator George Mitchell, the majority leader, called it unwise and Senator Paul Sarbanes, who will take over next year as chairman of the banking committee, urged the Fed to 'leave the economy alone'. 'The economy is doing pretty well but every time the Fed takes the rates up it dampens economic activity,' he said. Many business groups share this concern. But the financial markets side firmly with the Fed on the need to deal with brewing signs of inflation. Even an increase of a quarter of a percentage point yesterday would have been greeted with disappointment as a sign that the Fed was 'behind the curve' on inflation. The members of the Federal Open Market Committee are less godlike in their certitude than the markets. They appear to have taken to heart Oliver Cromwell's advice to the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland: 'I beseech you, in the bowels of Christ, think it possible you may be mistaken.' Mr Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, put it a little differently last week in testimony to a congressional committee last week. 'Policy making requires an assessment of the consequences of various policy alternatives should they prove to be wrong. We must ask ourselves: how difficult would it be to reverse policy mistakes and at what cost?' The committee also includes five presidents of regional Federal Reserve banks. They stay in close touch with business leaders in their districts, and several of them have in recent weeks made a concerted effort to justify higher interest rates in speeches to community leaders and chambers of commerce. Fed officials say they have not been fully convinced by signs of an economic slowdown in some recent statistics, such as the large increase in business inventories in the second quarter, and argue that the capacity of the job market and industrial plant to absorb more demand is becoming stretched. The Fed said yesterday that its half point increase in rates was 'expected to be sufficient, at least for a time, to meet the objective of sustained, non-inflationary growth.' That probably averts the likelihood of further tightening at next month's committee meeting, but does not appear to rule out the possibility of another increase before the end of the year. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1994.

headline: FED LIFTS SHORT-TERM RATES TO STEM INFLATION PRESSURE.
content: Discount rate up half a point; US bonds and stocks rally; Banks increase loan costs. By GEORGE GRAHAM. The US Federal Reserve yesterday lifted short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year, adding half a percentage point in an effort to head off inflation rises. After a morning meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets interest rate policy, the Fed announced that it was increasing the discount rate which it charges on money lent to the banking system to 4% from 3.5%. The Fed is also raising the federal funds rate, which banks charge each other on overnight balances, to 4.75% from 4.25%. Although an increase in rates had been widely expected, investors and dealers were unsure whether the Fed would raise rates by a quarter of a point or make the sharper adjustment that came yesterday. On Wall Street, the news triggered a surge in bond prices and brought solid gains to stocks. The markets had stumbled briefly in the minutes after the Fed's announcement, but quickly picked up forward momentum during the afternoon. Chase Manhattan raised its prime lending rate for its best business customers to 7.75% from 7.25% in the wake of the Fed move and other banks followed suit. White House officials have repeatedly said that they see no signs of inflation rises that would require a tightening of monetary policy, but add that the Fed is independent. 'Given the strong gains in output and employment so far this year, we need to be watchful for signs of developing price pressures,' Mr Lloyd Bentsen, US Treasury secretary, and Ms Laura Tyson, White House chief economist, said in a joint statement yesterday. Democratic senators, however, were less sparing in their criticism. 'If you're bored down there at the Fed, if a rosy economic outlook makes you blue, get out of town, take a vacation, do any thing, but just don't raise those interest rates,' Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona said before the Fed move. Fed officials note that they kept interest rates very low to try to boost sluggish recovery in 1992 and 1993. 'In fact, real short term rates - that is, adjusted for inflation - were around zero levels throughout last year,' Mr Robert Parry, president of the San Francisco Fed, said last week. Most recent economic data have suggested that the economy has slowed considerably, and is growing at a much steadier pace than the 3.7% annualised rate of the second quarter. However, July's employment statistics showed that job creation remained strong, and the producer price index, published last Thursday, showed a 0.5% bounce in wholesale prices last month. Fed officials say that policy actions only show their effects about one-and-a-half to two years later, and that they cannot be deterred by the apparently calm inflation indices. Some Fed economists argue that full employment is now reached when the unemployment rate stands at around 6% - very close to its current level. Any further drop in unemployment, they say, could lead to shortages of labour and be expected to provoke an acceleration in the inflation rate. After the early pause, prices on longer-dated Treasury bonds climbed nearly 1 1/2 points on the rate rise, even though most analysts had anticipated the Fed's course of action. Traders appeared reassured by the apparent resolve of the Fed's chairman, Mr Alan Greenspan, to snuff out inflationary pressures. In the equity markets, the rate rise triggered a brief rally, but in minutes a 20-point gain by the Dow Jones Industrial Average was converted into a 15-point loss. By the close, however, it was up 24.28 at 3,784.57. In Tokyo today, stocks opened firmer. The Bundesbank, which has a policy meeting tomorrow, is expected to let the dust settle after the Fed move. Economists see scope for a German discount rate cut, but believe the bank's 'steady hand' policy will prevail. Fed 'stays with the curve', Page 4 Editorial Comment, Page 13 Lex, Page 14 Bonds, Page 20 Currencies, Page 23 World stocks, Page 29 London stocks, Page 32 (c) The Financial Times Limited 1994.

headline: LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE - EQUITY FUTURES AND OPTIONS TRADING.
content: Stock index futures traded in a tight range as dealers waited for the outcome of discussions at yesterday's Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Confirmation of a rise in US interest rates came well after the market close, writes Joel Kibazo. The September contract on the FT-SE 100 opened at 3,155 and languished in the first hour. The lower than expected PSBR figure cheered the market, sending the contract ahead to reach a peak of 3,169. However, a combination of profit-taking together with concerns that the FMOC would raise interest rates saw the contract give up the early gains. Following a bout of sideways trading over the lunchtime period, September again moved forward, this time encouraged by the firm opening on Wall Street. But the worries on interest rates remained, which brought another setback and September finished just ahead of the day's low at 3,153, a point ahead of its previous close and at a 5-point premium to cash. Volume at 6,766 lots remained low. Traded options stayed dull and total turnover was 22,268 lots. Two big trades in Hanson puts were the only outstanding feature in the stock options. They were said to have been carried out by Kleinwort Benson and Monument. Volume was 3,481. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1994.

headline: LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE - US RATE RISE DECISION TOO LATE TO AFFECT LONDON - MARKET REPORT.
content: The London stock market was again preoccupied with watching for any signs of a precursor to a shift in US interest rates, eventually ending a tense but largely boring session marginally higher on balance. The FT-SE 100 Index settled with a net gain of 5.1 at 3,147.3, having moved in a narrow range throughout the day. The FT-SE Mid 250 Index delivered another uninspiring performance, closing 4.1 lower at 3,715.1. While dealers remained on alert for the rise in US rates, which could impact on the large number of UK stocks traded on Wall Street, the move of 50 basis points in the Fed Funds rate came two hours after London closed. The market began the trading session in subdued fashion with marketmakers lowering their opening prices in the wake of an eight-point fall on the Dow Industrial Average. The early decline proved short-lived, however, as a lower than expected public sector borrowing requirement number of #1.1bn, compared with a consensus figure up around #1.5bn, boosted gilt-edged stocks and produced a keen rally in the equity market. Gilts were also supported by the latest survey of disitributive trades published by the Confederation of British Industry which pointed to a slowing of retail sales, a move interpreted in the City as reducing the possibility of an early increase in UK interest rates. Down some three points at the outset, the FT-SE 100 moved into positive territory within the hour, gradually climbing to reach the day's high point of 3,151.6, up 9.4, shortly after Wall Street opened and while the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting was in progress. But with Wall Street faltering, before embarking on another good rise after London had closed, the UK market began to ease off. As well as having to contend with an expected rise in US interest rates, the market has to face a welter of domestic economic news this morning. This will include unemployment figures for July, average earnings and, most importantly, inflation numbers for last month. Some forecasters are looking for a negative inflation result month on month. Turnover yesterday came out at 511.8m shares, with non-FT-SE 100 stocks accounting for around 57% of activity. The value of customer business on Monday was a slightly disappointing #1.145bn. Meanwhile, a buzz of excitement went around the trading desks in the late afternoon as dealers picked up whispers that a big FT-SE 100 bid could be in the offing. GEC was one name being bandied about as a potential bid target for one of the big conglomerates such as BTR or Hanson. This story was mostly dismissed by analysts, who pointed out that GEC was much more likely to emerge as a predator than a target. And traders again began to focus on the obvious benefits of a merger between British Aerospace and GEC, which have been involved in tentative merger talks in the past. There was heavy trading in GEC stock, with one leading UK broking house said to have bought the stock aggressively, while British Aerospace shares were being chased in the market. Marketmakers also pointed out that GEC was in a strong position to buy in its own shares. Another takeover candidate, according to the market, was Wellcome, the pharmaceuticals group, with Glaxo one name being mooted. The regional electricity stocks were also being viewed as potential takeover targets. Bank shares continued to attract switching, with HSBC again badly affected by worries of static underlying profits growth. Bank of Scotland and Standard Chartered were the prime beneficiaries of the stories. Dealers pointed to Goldman Sachs, UBS and Morgan Stanley as brokers advising the switch. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1994.

headline: WORLD STOCK MARKETS - EUROPE - FRANKFURT, ZURICH SPECULATE ON FOMC MEETING.
content: With any decision on US interest rates from the FOMC in Washington consigned to the American afternoon, bourses could only speculate on the result, writes Our Markets Staff. FRANKFURT had its fun in the post bourse as the September bund future took a view on the Washington meeting, and jumped 44 basis points to 91.99 on the proposition that the Fed would impose a 50-point rate rise later in the US day, a forecast that was later confirmed. After a rise of just 4.30 to 2,143.14 in the Dax on the session, the post bourse saw an Ibis-indicated peak of 2,158.13 before it closed at 2,152.65. However, Ms Barbara Altmann at B Metzler in Frankfurt, said there was little trading as investors bided their time ahead of the FOMC decision; short-covering, she added, took the Dax constituents up in the afternoon. Turnover rose from DM 5.1bn to DM 6.6bn. Schering, the pharmaceuticals group, dropped DM 42.50 to DM 915 as it said that two of its drugs were under examination, and regained only DM 6 after hours after stating that neither were carcinogenic and calling a press conference for tomorrow morning to elaborate. Construction stocks were strong, Strabag rising DM 17.50 to DM 510.50 on a 20% increase in orders in the first half of 1994. In chemicals, BASF rose DM 4.90 to DM 327.20 as its Wintershall subsidiary forecast a profit from its gas operations in 1995, a year earlier than originally planned. AMSTERDAM recovered all of Monday's losses, helped by good gains in a number of the blue chips. The AEX index improved 1.89 to 417.07. Unilever rose Fl 3.10 to Fl 199.60, a number of brokers having issued positive reports following last week's results. Among them was James Capel, which reiterated its buy recommendation and remained optimistic about earnings per share growth during 1995 and 1996. Philips and KPN also saw buying strength as they announced plans to establish a joint venture, together with Graff Pay-Per-View, of the US, to provide a new media service in Europe. Philips put on 30 cents at Fl 58.20 and KPN added 70 cents at Fl 50.50. Hunter Douglas shed Fl 1.30 to Fl 83.70 as profits were taken following its better than expected results, while Wolters Kluwer added Fl 1.50 at Fl 120.50 after announcing a 23% gain in first-half profits and forecasting 20% growth over the full year. MILAN returned after Monday's holiday and continued to monitor the political temperature, following last week's unexpected rise in interest rates and a weekend of meetings between coalition partners in Mr Silvio Berlusconi's government. The Comit index closed 9.72 higher at 654.15. Analysts expect the nervousness to continue, with the 1995 budget due to be presented to parliament before September 30. Among individual performances, Fiat advanced L35 to L6,385, Benetton rose L650 to L22,450 and Olivetti L75 to L2,195. ZURICH took the Frankfurt line on FOMC prospects and the SMI index rose 18.1 to 2,588.7. Roche certificates and Nestle were the most active stocks, with gains either side of 1%. In banks, UBS recovered with a rise of SwFr 25 to SwFr 1,112, and SBC bearers rose SwFr 3 to SwFr 397 ahead of results which arrived after hours. However, analysts flinched when they saw the figures, which included a 63% drop in first-half trading income, and said that the shares would tumble today. MADRID fell against the trend, the general index losing 1.71 at 311.18. Bonds were slightly firmer but most banks were down, with BBV off Pta45 at Pta3,040 and BCH Pta80 at Pta2,665. ADR stocks such as Endesa, Pta50 lower at Pta6,010, and Repsol, down Pta95 at Pta3,930, became less attractive as Wall Street lost its impetus late in the European day. PARIS drifted higher in a session that was characterised by a lack of corporate news. The CAC-40 index improved 5.40 to 2,012.35 in thin turnover of about FFr 2bn. STOCKHOLM staged a modest recovery as the market reversed three days of losses. Ericsson, the telecommunications group, provided the main support for the market, but shares in the forestry sector were also strong. The Affarsvarlden general index was little changed, down 0.3 at 1,400.3, in moderate turnover of SKr2.2bn. Ericsson B shares rose SKr4 to SKr393 ahead of tomorrow's six-month figures, while Electrolux lost SKr3 at SKr368 in spite of reporting an improvement in half-year results. TEL AVIV fell another 2%, the Mishtanim index closing 3.74 lower at 183.40 after the Israeli finance minister Mr Avraham Shohat said Israel's 1994 inflation rate would be double digit, revising an official forecast of 8%. Mr Shohat had more news for the market after hours when he proposed a capital gains tax on share profits, specifically a 10% tax on real profits from share investments. He said that the market would be closed on Wednesday and Thursday to ease the way for his recommendation. Written and edited by William Cochrane and John Pitt (c) The Financial Times Limited 1994.

headline: Consensus reflects easing and rates trade-off
content: No plans to expand asset purchases 'Output gap' guards against inflation The Federal Reserve is on hold - but it expects quite a long time to pass before it starts raising interest rates again. That is the basic message from yesterday's statement. The central bank did not increase its planned asset purchases, which amounts to no additional easing. However, it simultaneously rebuffed market expectations of early rate increases. The Fed said it "continues to anticipate that economic conditions are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels of the federal funds rate for an extended period". It noted that "prices of energy and other commodities have risen" and importantly dropped a reference to deflation risk. But it said "substantial resource slack is likely to dampen cost pressures" and added that it "expects that inflation will remain subdued for some time". These last three words were new and reinforce the message. This reflects the view of Ben Bernanke, the Fed chairman, and Don Kohn, Fed vice-chairman, that a large and growing output gap between demand and potential supply provides a strong safeguard against inflation. The decision was unanimous, with more hawkish members of the Federal Open Market Committee apparently accepting the guidance on interest rates in return for no increase in Treasury purchases. The central bank said it would continue to evaluate the "timing and overall amounts of its purchases of securities" - leaving open the possibility that it could still adjust its Treasury -purchase plan at or before its next meeting. "I think there is still a good chance that in order to avoid the cliff edge effect they will stretch it out and may change the mix between Treasuries and mortgages," said Richard Berner, chief US economist at Morgan Stanley. But the lack of any clear signal on this in the statement suggests the Fed is not predisposed to expand the Treasury programme and might simply complete it as scheduled in September. Peter Hooper, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities said: "They are delivering more or less the promised degree of stimulus, in the context of an economy where the news is improving and rates are backing up." The Fed did say it would "make adjustments to its credit and liquidity programmes as warranted". One interpretation of this phrase is that the Fed wants to retain flexibility to tweak its programmes even if the overall stance of policy is hold. Another is that this was an oblique reference to the gradual phasing out of some programmes as market conditions improve. There was no explicit reference to exit strategy. The US central bank marked up its assessment of current economic conditions, but did not radically reappraise its economic -outlook. It said the pace of the recession was "slowing" and said conditions in financial markets "have generally improved". There were "further signs of -stabilising" household spending, while businesses "appear to be making progress" on inventories. However, the Fed said household spending "remains constrained by ongoing job losses, lower housing wealth and tight credit" while business were "cutting back on fixed investment and staffing". It reiterated its cautious view that "economic activity is likely to remain weak for a time". While the immediate market response was to sell Treasuries and push up yields, on the grounds that the Fed was not buying any more of them, Bill Gross, founder of Pimco, told CNBC he was surprised by this response and thought yields on short-term securities should trade lower on the statement.

headline: Oracle sets positive tone for blue chips despite mixed data
content: wall street US stocks bounced yesterday morning as Oracle boosted the technology sector and investors focused on the positives in a mixed bag of economic data. The software maker helped the technology sector top the benchmark S&P 500 index after reporting sales and profit that were better than Wall Street had expected. Its shares gained 8.7 per cent to $21.60. Two of Oracle's biggest rivals also felt the benefit with Microsoft rising 1.2 per cent to $23.63 and IBM up 1.3 per cent at $105.83. On a busy day for economic data, the markets were reassured by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which upgraded its forecasts for US growth for 2009 and 2010. The OECD's 2009 forecast is now slightly better than that from the World Bank, whose downgrade of its forecast on Monday helped trigger that day's sell-off. Stocks were given added impetus by figures showing that durable goods orders unexpectedly rose during May. Lower demand for cars had been expected to drag the number lower and the figures helped Ford climb 5.3 per cent to $5.83. Meanwhile, materials producers and industrial companies performed well. Metals stocks continued Tuesday's recovery following a sharp sell-off on Monday, boosted by the durable goods numbers and higher commodity prices. Alcoa , which produces aluminium, rose 4.9 per cent to $10.49 while Free-port McMoRan , the copper miner, which was upgraded by Friedman Billings Ramsey, picked up 6.4 per cent to $50.20. AK Steel advanced 5.5 per cent to $18.65 and Caterpillar , which makes machinery for the mining industry, was 3.6 per cent higher at $34.17. The materials sector was initially given an extra boost by results from Monsanto , the agricultural giant, which beat estimates with its quarterly earnings. But the shares fell 1.5 per cent to $78.15 after the company said gross profit from its Roundup herbicide would fall roughly 50 per cent because of increased competition. The markets dipped in early trade after figures were released showing that new home sales unexpectedly fell in May but stocks then quickly recovered. "The fact that the market completely shrugged off the new home sales data had me stunned," said Dan Cook, senior market analyst at IG Markets. "But technology and materials stocks seem to be providing support right now." By midday, the benchmark S&P 500 index was up 1.5 per cent to 908.56. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.9 per cent to 8,396.90 and the Nasdaq Composite index picked up 2.2 per cent to 1,803.72. Many on Wall Street remained cautious ahead of the end of the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, however, with investors looking for signals on when the Federal Reserve might implement an exit strategy from its stimulus programme. Financial stocks were higher after figures showed mortgage applications rose last week as interest rates dropped from recent levels. They then continued to climb in spite of suffering a brief dip on the new home sales data. By midday, Wells Fargo , which Citi said yesterday would see sufficient business in its mortgage department to give it strong second-quarter results, was 1.4 higher at $23.22. Citigroup also picked up ground, helped by the news that it intends to increase employees' base salaries in 2009 as part of an effort to retain top talent. Its shares climbed 1.3 per cent to $3.05. Meanwhile, Darden Restaurants , which owns several leading US mid-market chains, including Olive Garden and Red Lobster, also beat estimates with its earnings but its shares fell as the company warned 2010 would not be as good a year as hoped. The stock lost 1.9 per cent to $32.39. There was more bad news from the supermarket chain SuperValu , which warned lower customer spending would see quarterly results come in substantially below analysts' predictions. The stock fell 11.9 per cent to $13.83 and the words also had an effect on its rival Kroger , which reported lower quarterly revenues than expected on Tuesday. Kroger's shares lost 1.2 per cent to $21.51.

headline: Dramatic action from Europe's central bank
content: GLOBAL OVERVIEW Libor falls after ECB injects 442bn Fed likely to play down rate rises Central banks dominated financial market action yesterday as the ECB lent record funds to eurozone banks, the Swiss National Bank moved to weaken the franc and investors awaited the outcome of a Federal Reserve policy meeting. The European Central Bank pumped 442bn ($617bn) into the banking system at a rate of 1 per cent in its first-ever offer of one-year funds - more than analysts had expected. Lorenzo Bini Smaghi, an executive of the ECB's executive board, said that banks must now lend on the funds they had borrowed. In the money markets , the three-month euro Libor rate fell 2.6 basis points to a record low of 1.185 per cent. "My gut feeling is that all the spare cash flushing around now will drive yields still lower for the next week or two," said Erik Nielsen, chief European economist at Goldman Sachs. "If I had to make a guess, I could well see three-month money 25bp-50bp cheaper by mid-July, which would be about the easing the ECB probably is looking for." But Christoph Rieger at Commerzbank warned that the excess liquidity posed new challenges for markets and the ECB. "The amounts involved are so huge that the ECB may not be able to sit on its hands and leave the market to itself." Mr Rieger added that "inactivity would . . . leave overnight rates pinned significantly below the ECB's main policy rate for quite some time and, more importantly, money market functioning could be impaired with so much excess reserves in the system." The ECB's move drove the euro lower against the dollar and pushed up short-dated European government bonds. On the currency markets , the euro dipped 0.3 per cent against the dollar and 0.7 per cent against sterling. But it rose sharply against the Swiss franc after the Swiss National Bank again stepped into the markets to drive its currency lower in a bid to protect Switzerland's manufacturing sector. The dollar was softer against most higher-yielding currencies as investors awaited the outcome of a two-day meeting of the Federal Reserve. The US central bank was widely expected to play down market expectations of an early rise in interest rates. "The Federal Open market Committee is expected to reiterate its commitment to keeping policy rates low for an 'extended period'," said David Greenlaw, Morgan Stanley's chief US fixed income economist, although he added: "We doubt that the Fed will cite a particular date." Uncertainty ahead of the Fed's post-meeting comments and fresh concerns about forthcoming supply put pressure on US government bonds . The yield on the 10-year Treasury was up 4bp at 3.67 per cent and the 30-year was 7bp higher at 4.43 per cent. By contrast, the two-year German Schatz yield fell 8bp to 1.41 per cent following the ECB's action and a gloomy assessment of the eurozone's prospects from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. "The new OECD forecasts still see the eurozone as an underperformer, with a contraction in real GDP of nearly 5 per cent this year followed by stagnation next year - signalling the need for the ECB to exhaust the remaining scope for interest rate cuts sooner rather than later," said Marco Annunziata, UniCredit's chief economist. However, the OECD was more upbeat about the global outlook, saying the prospects for economic recovery next year had improved for the first time in two years. The comments, along with robust US durable goods data and strong earnings from software group Oracle, provided a more solid backdrop for equity markets. Investors largely shrugged off disappointing home sales figures. By midday in New York, the S&P 500 was up 1.5 per cent, while the FTSE Eurofirst 300 index gained 2.4 per cent and the Nikkei 225 Average in Tokyo rose 0.4 per cent. In commodities , oil inched higher but failed to regain the $70 a barrel level as weekly US data showed a big drop in crude stockpiles. Copper's push back above $5,000 a tonne led a broad advance in base metals as sentiment was lifted by hopes of increased demand. Gold edged ahead as news from the Fed was awaited.

headline: Won and yen retreat on recovery fears
content: Asian currencies retreated on Thursday on growing fears that the region's economic recovery would lag behind that of the US. On Wednesday the Federal Open Market Committee meeting delivered the expected result - no change in US monetary policy and a toning down in inflation expectations - leaving investors with a clearer message that policy measures would not be withdrawn in the near future. The Fed was also slightly more upbeat on growth prospects, noting that the pace of contraction in the economy was slowing. This was in contrast to the picture developing in South Korea, where, in spite of an upward revision to the government's economic outlook for this year, exports continued to fall while domestic spending weakened. "The recovery of private domestic demand will probably remain gradual as the debt burden of household and corporate sectors persists," said Suktae Oh at Citigroup. "Export growth is likely to slow as the recent strength, driven by inventory restocking, should be limited by the limited recovery in final demand." By midday in New York, the Korean won had fallen 0.7 per cent against the dollar, to Won1,258.10, and was 0.3 per cent lower against the yen to Won13.3670. Elsewhere, the yen was down across the board on fears that the rising risk of lower prices will keep the Bank of Japan hamstrung long after other central banks have started removing their accommodative policy measures. Antje Praefcke at Commerzbank said: "Today's Japanese inflation data are likely to show ongoing rising deflation risks, and this trend should continue, supporting our view that the yen will weaken further in the months to come." Meanwhile, the latest portfolio flow data showed Japanese investors were heavy buyers of foreign bonds. The yen fell 0.5 per cent against the dollar to Y96.13 and was down 0.4 per cent versus the euro to Y133.89. The dollar edged 0.1 per cent lower to $1.3920 against the euro. The Swiss franc remained on the back foot after Wednesday's intervention by Swiss monetary authorities to weaken the currency. It was down 0.1 per cent against the euro to SFr1.5308 and was 0.2 per cent weaker against the dollar at SFr1.0994. Sterling was weighed down by comments on Wednesday from Mervyn King, governor of the Bank of England, describing Britain's road to economic recovery as "a long, hard slog". The pound fell 0.8 per cent against the dollar to $1.6276 and was down 0.9 per cent to 0.8550 against the euro.

headline: US economy contracts by revised 5.5%
content: The US economy continued to contract in the first quarter of this year, but at a slower pace than previously thought, official figures showed on Thursday. Separately, the labour department said that new claims for unemployment benefits grew more than expected last week, offering a stark reminder that even as the economy turns around the stricken labour market could be slow to follow. Revised commerce department figures revealed that US gross domestic product declined by an annualised rate of 5.5 per cent in the first three months of the year. That was better than economists expected and a smaller contraction than the original estimate of a 6.1 per cent contraction and last month's estimate of a 5.7 per cent decline. Output is slowly beginning to rekindle in the US economy, which has been mired in its worst recession in the last 50 years. The first quarter result, while grim, was an improvement from the end of 2008 when GDP declined by 6.3 per cent, the steepest fall since 1982. Economists expect to see more significant improvement in the second quarter of this year. On Wednesday the Federal Reserve said in its Federal Open Market Committee statement that economy activity was likely "remain weak for a time" but that sustainable economic growth would then resume gradually while inflation remains "subdued". Meanwhile the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development improved its outlook for the US and predicted the economy would grow by 0.9 per cent next year. Housing and manufacturing have shown signs of life lately. Home prices and sales have begun to stabilise in some areas and businesses have begun to ramp up their capital investment with more orders for durable goods. However, analysts fear that rising joblessness could slow the recovery. The labour department said on Thursday that initial jobless claims rose by 15,000 to 627,000 last week. That was more than expected and boosted the four-week average to 617,250. The number of Americans continuing to claim unemployment benefits rose in the second week of the month to 6.74m, up from 6.71m the prior week. "With initial claims still very high at above 600,000, it is unlikely that new hiring has picked up in any meaningful fashion," said Joshua Shapiro, chief US economist at MFR. "More probable is that long-term unemployed are starting to fall off the rolls as the duration of their unemployment benefits reaches the statutory limit." The US unemployment rate rose to 9.4 per cent last month and is expected to climb to 9.6 per cent in June.

headline: Capital raising rumour hits Crdit Agricole
content: Crdit Agricole shares fell on Thursday amid market rumours that the bank was looking at a possible capital raising. Traders said the rumour was making its way around the market and was not surprising, but had not been confirmed. Shares in the French bank lost 3.8 per cent to 9.15. CA shares were also hit by concerns over the profit outlook for the French bank. Kepler Capital Markets cut its rating to "hold" from "buy" and lowered the 2009 profit estimate for 2009 to 945m from 1.92bn. Kepler noted that that it expects additional losses from Emporiki, the heavily indebted Greek bank in which Crdit Agricole has a 72 per cent stake. In the wider market, European bourses were lower, with the Federal Reserve's comments on Wednesday evening leading investors to look ahead to the US central bank's "exit strategy" and a withdrawal of market stimulus measures. The Fed did not change interest rate levels and did not expand its planned asset purchases. Ed McKelvey at Goldman Sachs noted several aspects of the FOMC statement that were more hawkish than expected. "The committee is less worried about extreme downside risks than it was in late April and therefore less inclined to take further steps toward accommodation," he said. The FTSE Eurofirst 300 fell 1.1 per cent to 844.00. France's CAC 40 index lost 1.1 per cent to 3,150.74 and Germany's Xetra Dax was down 1.2 per cent to 4,777.91. European markets have been quite volatile all week, hits their lows on Tuesday. Resource shares negated some of Wednesday's gains as sentiment evolved, steelmaker ArcelorMittal fell 2.7 per cent to 23.07, Norsk Hydro lost 1.6 per cent to NKr34.05 and Eramet was 1.4 per cent lower at 183.00. Elsewhere, Porsche shares were some of the strongest of morning trading gaining 4.6 per cent to 45.09 following a late afternoon surge in the previous session. Share prices were boosted by rumours that the debt-ridden sportscar maker was nearing a deal to sell its Volkswagen stake to Qatar. Volkswagen shares fell 0.7 per cent to 248.69 after gaining 11.7 per cent in the previous session. Telecom Italia shares rose 3.5 per cent to 0.98 after positive analyst comments. Goldman Sachs said: "We expect Telecom Italia to outperform peers as accelerating cost reduction activities, an improving domestic competitive environment and a successful turnaround at TIM Brasil increase confidence." Bouygues announced it had signed a contract to design and built a new deep-water port in Tangier. The contract will be worth 335m to Bouygues, with the work estimated to take around four and a half years. Goldman Sachs upgraded the French construction conglomerate to "buy" from "neutral", and its shares were lifted 3.6 per cent to 27.62. Swedish clothing company Hennes & Mauritz reported a 6 per cent increase in pre-tax profits in the second quarter, compared to the same period a year earlier. Europe's second-largest clothing retailer's stock was 1.5 per cent higher at SKr376.00, but Alessandra Coppola, equity analyst at S&P, reiterated a "sell" recommendation. "May sales disappointed at -9 per cent year-on-year, in line with our expectations but missing consensus (-8 per cent) and indicating an unsupportive trading environment," she said in a note.

headline: An open commitment - A call for more transparency in British monetary management.
content: An open commitment - Gordon Pepper and Anthony Harris call for more transparency in British monetary management. The crisis of confidence which has undermined sterling in the past few days is mainly due to uncertainty about government policy. Yet in countries where monetary policy is not under political control, political difficulties do not normally turn into financial crises. This has led to proposals that the Bank of England should be made independent. We doubt whether this would, of itself, solve the British problem, which is not due only to political interference. The monetary regime has changed frequently and radically over many years, with little success. Monetary targets have regularly been missed. Decisions are made in secret, and are seldom explained, so market doubts go unanswered. Monetary targets will now take the place of exchange rate discipline; but the same forces which have driven Britain out of the ERM will make monetary control more difficult. International flows distort the monetary aggregates in ways which are not yet fully understood, and floating exchange rates have proved very hard to stabilise. The government further proposes that targets should include not only the exchange rate, but also broad and narrow measures of money, and housing and other asset prices. These indicators look well chosen, and would have alerted the authorities to many recent problems. But though the approach is described as new, it is essentially the traditional British system, and revives an old problem. It is impossible to keep multiple targets always in the sights of a single weapon, the interest rate regime. Something on the list will always look out of line; and sometimes objectives will be incompatible, as they are now. Policy cannot both support the exchange rate, and reduce real interest rates so as to relieve debtors and restore the growth of credit and money. Policy must be a compromise. Market acceptance will, therefore, depend on restoring confidence in official judgment. That is the aim of our proposal: to enable the markets to monitor the reasoning behind policy decisions, and to strengthen the policy process by bringing in well-regarded outsiders. Proposal: the UK should set up an Open Market Committee (OMC), similar to the FOMC of the US Federal Reserve. This would have full executive responsibility for monetary policy. At the moment the chancellor is nominally responsible, but the Bank and Number 10 Downing Street make their own inputs. When any policy fails, the buck passes rapidly round this triangle; this may be intended to protect reputations, but further undermines confidence. An OMC could not disown its decisions in this way; Publication: honest differences of opinion will always arise in matters of policy. The market is likely to have more confidence in decisions - even those which prove mistaken - if it knows what facts and interpretations were involved in reaching them. The minutes of the OMC should, therefore, be published after a minimum delay, as are those of the FOMC (six weeks in arrears). They should report the sometimes dissenting views expressed in reaching a decision, and should also include the committee's assessment of each of the indicators for policy, with full explanation if any is judged misleading at the time. We believe that disclosure on these lines would increase market confidence, partly by reducing uncertainty; Outside directors: British monetary policy is managed by a committee of Bank and Treasury officials. It usually maintains an outside appearance of unanimity and confidence. This has never been fully convincing; at a time when policy has gone off the rails, and leaks tell of furious internal arguments (as after every British crisis), the pretence simply undermines confidence further. Compared with this, the federal structure of the US and German central banks has important advantages. The heads of the Fed districts and the Landesbanks have their own power base, their own local information, and they often hold strongly independent views which are widely known. This assures markets that policy decisions are fully informed and largely politician-proof. It would be hard to imitate such a structure in the UK; but some of the same advantages could be secured by including outside directors or advisers in the OMC. These 'non-executive directors' should not be officials either of the Bank or of the Treasury. As 'insiders', they could not be active in the City during their time on the OMC. They would have a threefold role: to ensure that policy-making is fully informed about private-sector views and problems; to ensure that the OMC minutes convey meaningful information about policy decisions; and to act as potential whistle-blowers if they strongly disagree with the OMC consensus. They should be encouraged to propound and debate policy i n public, as do the directors of the Fed and the Bundesbank; Execution: the OMC would steer policy, and answer for it; but day-to-day execution would remain in the hands of the Bank. We believe this structure would improve the operations of an independent Bank of England. It would be even more important if the Bank is not made formally independent. Gordon Pepper is professor of financial markets at City University Business School; Anthony Harris is an FT columnist. The Financial Times. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1992.

headline: Government Bonds - Sterling's rally encourages short and medium gilts.
content: A rally in sterling lifted prices in the short and medium-dated gilts, though the long end of the market remained in the doldrums. Dealers said yesterday's improvement was partly a technical correction after the market was oversold on Monday. Trading conditions proved volatile yesterday, with the long gilt future opening up 11/32 at 95.16, before falling back to close at 94.30. But the shorter end of the market performed well, recording gains of as much as 3/8 point. 'Sterling holds the key at the moment,' said Mr Phillip Tyson, an economist at UBS Phillips and Drew. The improvement in sterling revived hopes that a further reduction in interest rates would be possible sooner rather than later. The short sterling contract on the London International Financial Futures Exchange gained 6 basis points to close at 91.75. However, dealers expected trading conditions to remain volatile at least until firm details of the government's economic policy emerge following sterling's withdrawal from the exchange rate mechanism. The market will listen keenly to the Chancellor of the Exchequer's speech tomorrow for hints of the form the new economic policy will take. High-yielding European bond markets continued their meteoric fall yesterday. Italian government bonds shed 1 1/2 points, as the lira dived yesterday morning, but recovered some ground later in the day. Spanish bonds fared poorly, recording losses of 1 3/8 points. Non-resident selling pressure pushed prices down further, as fears of a peseta devaluation and worries about the lifting of capital controls depressed sentiment further. Dealers said liquidity in the Spanish bond market was particularly poor. GERMAN bund prices were forced to surrender some of the gains that they made on Monday, ending 1/4 point lower. Dealers said the market had got ahead of itself, but sentiment remained positive. The new 10-year 7 1/4% bund issue met firm demand, dealers said. The results are due to be announced today. Although the rush of buying seen on Monday appeared to have dried up, German bunds are expected to retain their safe haven status, since economic fundamentals remain favourable. The German bund future on Liffe closed at 91.38, down from Monday's close of 91.70. DUTCH bonds fell back after their opening rise, following a steep fall in German bund futures. Dealers said bond prices had gone too high and fell back as stock market turbulence faded. An increased supply from tap issue had also brought prices down, dealers said. BELGIUM will issue a new state loan aimed at private investors between November 12 and November 18, the Belgian Finance Ministry said, Reuter reports from Brussels. The maturity, coupon and issue price will be set later. The previous state loan in June raised BFr 58.5bn and one in February brought in BFr 66bn. FRENCH bond prices fell a further half point yesterday, as benefits from the fall in stock prices on Monday evaporated. Dealers said the concerns of currency weakness continued to preoccupy the market. The OAT future on the Matif ended 0.58 point down at 108.56. JAPANESE bonds again performed inversely to the stock market, gaining ground during early stock market weakness, then falling back when equity prices rallied later in the day. The JGB future on Liffe ended unchanged at 106.87, in thin trade. LONGER-DATED US Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday on disappointment that the Federal Reserve's monthly federal open market committee (FOMC), which met during the day, did not ease monetary policy to help the ailing economy. In late trading, the benchmark 30-year government bond was down 13/16 at 98, yielding 7.411%. The two-year note was also lower, down 1/8 at 100 17/32 to carry a yield of 3.735%. In the absence of economic news, the market's attention was focused on yesterday's FOMC meeting. Speculation has mounted in recent days that the FOMC would sanction another cut in interest rates (possibly a 25 basis-point reduction in the federal funds rate and a 50 basis-point reduction in the discount rate) to lift the apparently stalled economic recovery. A policy ease has been partly discounted by the market, and the lack of a move from the Fed yesterday meant that some of those gains had to be given back. The Financial Times. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1992.

headline: World Stock Markets (America) - Dow supported by hopes of a rate cut.
content: Wall Street US markets settled down with share prices holding their ground amid mounting speculation about a possible interest rate cut, writes Patrick Harverson in New York. At the close the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.81 at 3,178.19, the index having spent all but the first few minutes of the day only a few points either side of Monday's close. The more broadly based Standard and Poor's 500 was also virtually unchanged at the finish, down 0.41 at 407.16, while the Amex composite added 1.09 at 367.71 and the Nasdaq composite firmed 5.34 to 570.55. Turnover on the New York SE was 197m shares, and rises outpaced declines by 1033 to 727. Although the concerns about the economy and corporate earnings that were behind Monday's volatility were still dogging the market, investors switched their attention yesterday to the Federal Reserve's open market committee (FOMC), and prospects for a cut in interest rates. There was no sign from the committee of any policy shift yesterday, but many analysts were predicting that the FOMC would agree to a 25 basis-point cut in the federal funds rate, or a 50 basis point cut in the more important discount rate, or both. Normally, such predictions would have stimulated anticipatory buying, but in light of the market's unstable mood, investors were holding off until they had proof that rates were being cut. Among individual stocks, Citicorp dropped $3/4 to $14 3/4 in turnover of 3.3m shares after the bank announced that its third quarter profits would come in between eight cents and 13 cents a share, well below analysts' expectations. The stock's fall also represented investor concern about the sudden departure of the banking group's president, Mr Richard Braddock, who resigned on Monday night. Advanced Micro was one of the day's best performers, advancing $1 1/8 to $12 7/8 in turnover of 2.9m shares after the company unveiled third quarter net income of 51 cents a share, up sharply from the 16 cents a share of a year ago. Advanced Micro also said that it expected profits to grow even faster in the fourth quarter. Tyco Toys dropped $2 1/2 to $13 3/8 in heavy trading after an analyst at the broking house Salomon Brothers, downgraded the stock from a 'buy' to a 'hold' and cut his 1992 and 1993 earnings estimates, citing weak retail sales, an unfavourable sales mix and rising advertising costs. On the Nasdaq market, some of the leading stocks which tumbled on Monday bounced back, including Microsoft, up $3/4 at $82 1/2 and Amgen $1 1/4 higher at $60 3/4. Optrotech dropped $1 1/2 to $12 1/4 after the Federal Trade Commission asked the company to delay its merger with Orbot Systems because of concerns about the effect of the link-up on competition. CANADA Toronto stocks broke a week-long down fallending with marginal gains after a day of cautious trade, dealers said. After losing more than 150 points last week, the TSE 300 closed up 1.96 points at 3,229.49, after swinging within a 21-point range in the morning. Volume was 25.5m and transactions were valued at C$371m. The Financial Times. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1992.

headline: MARKETS REPORT - JUPPE SPEECH KEEPS FRENCH FRANC IN SPOTLIGHT.
content: The French franc remained the focus of attention yesterday as the market responded sceptically to a policy speech by Mr Alain Juppe, the new prime minister, writes Philip Gawith. Plans to tackle unemployment and raise the minimum wage were not well received and the franc lost ground, closing in London at FFr 3.559 per D-Mark, from FFr 3.542. The D-Mark was a general beneficiary of franc weakness, and made gains against most European crosses. It was also firmer against the dollar. Traders did report buying interest when the dollar dipped, an indication of the positive sentiment in the market. This was reinforced by lack of enthusiasm for taking the currency decisively lower. The dollar finished mildly down at DM 1.4362, from DM 1.4482. Against the yen it closed at Y 87.025 from Y 87.715. Opinion ahead of the FOMC meeting was practically unanimous that no change in policy should be expected. In New York the US currency ended at DM 1.4440 and Y 87.175. Sterling had little fresh news to chew on. It lost ground against the firmer D-Mark to close at DM 2.2563, from DM 2.2695. Against the dollar it finished at $1.5711 from $1.5672. The effect of Mr Juppe's speech was to confirm the market's worst expectations about a slide from economic rigour under the new government. Potential spending commitments were mentioned, without any compensating comments about deficit management. Mr Avinash Persaud, currency strategist at JP Morgan in London, said: 'I think it is going to be very hard for the new government to square the circle. The market senses that the one of those three objectives (cutting the deficit, cutting unemployment, and keeping the franc stable) the government is going to be less committed to than before is keeping the exchange rate strong.' Mr Persaud said the prospect of the franc revisiting FFr 3.60 could not be ruled out, but he did not think it would go to FFr 3.90, the upper limit of the EMS band. 'I do not think the Bundesbank will allow it to reach FFr 3.90,' he said. 'Above FFr 3.60 it becomes not just a French problem, but a German problem.' The main reason to cut rates again would be to alleviate the pressures German industry is feeling from a strong D-Mark. Mr Frank Newman, the US deputy treasury secretary, told the OECD gathering in Paris the perception that the US was trying to talk down the dollar was 'absolutely unfounded'. He also said that he saw the overall US trade deficit declining over time. Some economists believe a good US trade performance will be the catalyst for a dollar rally, making people happier to hold dollars, and increasing the prospect of higher US interest rates. Mr Toyoo Gyoten, a special adviser to Japan's Ministry of Finance, said the recent 'erratic' phase of the yen's rise appeared to be over. He forecast that it would trade in a fairly narrow range of about Y 85 to Y 90 to the dollar. He predicted that currencies would be discussed at the G7 summit in Halifax, but doubted whether any concerted action would result. 'They know the problem, they have a desire to cope with the problem and solve it, but I do not think they are collectively quite ready to launch some very concrete steps,' he said. Mr Gyoten acknowledged that Japan itself had not done enough to affect the fundamental economic change necessary. The Iranian government's attempts to peg the value of the rial at 3,000 rials to the dollar have met with a sceptical reception. The new regulations, which ban all dealings above the rate of 3,000 rials, were announced after the currency lost a third of its value in two weeks. Reports from Tehran indicate that little trade was being conducted, with market participants waiting to see how the new system settles down. Expectations are that the repo rate will stay at 4.51% in today's variable rate auction in Germany. The Bundesbank will not want to raise expectations of a move in official rates, by allowing a sharp drop in the repo, when it is not yet prepared for a follow-up. The Bank of England, in its daily operations, cleared a #550m shortage at established rates. Three-month LIBOR eased to 6 19/32%, from 6%. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1995.

headline: LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE - FT-SE FAILS IN LATEST ATTEMPT TO RECAPTURE 3,300 - MARKET REPORT.
content: The FT-SE 100-share Index just failed in its attempt to move back up through the 3,300 level. However, it survived a number of determined attempts by marketmakers and futures traders to get the market sharply lower. Once again it was Wall Street that came to the market's rescue. The Dow Average moved effortlessly back above the 4,400 mark shortly after it opened, with barely a ripple of unease about the Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Earlier, in what was said by marketmakers to have been an awkward trading session, share prices had come off sharply in the wake of poor preliminary results from Marks and Spencer, the UK's premier high street retailer and one of the world's top-rated companies. They also reacted to stricter than expected rules on cross-media ownership. The latter drove shares in many of the recently buoyant television companies sharply lower, while boosting some of the radio company stocks. Bolstered by Wall Street, the FT-SE 100 settled a net 7.3 firmer at 3,291.8. Second-line stocks fared less well, the FT-SE Mid 250 Index never looking likely to emulate the 100 index and finally ending the session only 1.1 points firmer at 3,605.7. The Mid 250 index was restrained by a dismal performance from the leading housebuilders, which provided the three poorest performers in Wimpey, Barratt Developments and Taylor Woodrow. They were badly affected by a television programme on Monday evening which predicted falling house prices in real terms in coming years. There were no problems for the market at the outset of trading after Wall Street once again had confounded the bears and jumped 54 points. Marketmakers lifted their opening prices and the FT-SE 100 had improved some 11 points shortly after trading commenced. The early strength was quickly dissipated, however, by the disappointing numbers from Marks and Spencer which confirmed the difficult trading conditions in the UK's high streets outlined last week by WH Smith. It was another dismal trading session for the retailing sector, with GUS taking the dubious honour of worst performer in the FT-SE 100 Index, followed by Boots in second place and M&S in fourth. The VSEL/GEC/BAe takeover saga, which has rumbled on since last year, took a series of twists as early reports that GEC would be prevented from continuing its bid for the submarine manufacturer were shot down by news that the Department of Trade and Industry had allowed both bids to proceed. With the bid now set to be contested in the market place, VSEL shares, sharply lower first thing, subsequently shot up to approach the level of the BAe offer, around #18 a share. After the Dow moved ahead strongly in the late afternoon, the Footsie ended in good heart. Nevertheless, senior dealers do not expect many fireworks for the rest of the week as most European markets are closed for the Ascension Day holiday. Turnover was 671.9m shares, with non-Footsie stocks accounting for 63% of the total. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1995.

headline: OVERSEAS NEWS - TREASURIES STEADY AFTER FOMC MEETING.
content: US Treasury prices were relatively steady at lower levels after the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee left interest rates unchanged after yesterday's meeting. Few had expected the Fed to lower interest rates after the surprisingly strong figures on February employment were released earlier this month. Treasury prices were lower as the Fed began its meeting at 8am and held at those levels after the FOMC meeting ended. But prices dipped later after Mr Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, told a senate panel that the economy was moving 'at a reasonably good clip'. Mr Greenspan, who was nominated by President Clinton to a third term at the Fed, testified before the Senate Banking Committee as part of the confirmation process. In early afternoon trading, the benchmark 30-year Treasury was 5/16 lower at 92 3/32 to yield 6.604%, and the two-year note was down 1/16 at 98 15/16, yielding 5.696%. Yesterday's losses came despite a new indication that consumer spending is not likely to spur economic growth in the near term. At mid-morning, the Conference Board reported that its index of consumer confidence slipped to 97.7 in March from 98 in February. Most economists had expected the figure to rise modestly to about 99. 'Although consumer attitudes, on balance, are pretty much in neutral territory, the uneasiness about the job market, coupled with concerns about future levels of income, do not suggest consumers are ready to spend more freely,' the Conference Board said. * Italy provided the focus for attention in Europe, with activity sparked by the suspension of the shares of Banco di Napoli and worries about the cost to the government of recapitalising the bank. On Liffe, Mr Alex Cooper, floor manager with Credit Lyonnaise Rouse, said many traders, who last week bought Italian bonds in the wake of consolidation in Europe and the US, moved quickly to reduce their exposures. As a result, volumes on Liffe were buoyant, with 52,510 contracts exchanged. The June future settled at 107.94, down just over a point. In the cash market, the 10-year yield spread over bunds widened to 448 basis points from 427 points on Monday. Mr David Brown, chief European economist at Bear Stearns, said the 'likely size of any recapitalisation is not huge but it has spooked BTPs nevertheless, catching the market on the defensive'. * Other European high-yielders had a mixed day. Spanish bonds closed marginally higher, with the 10-year yield spread over Germany falling from 333 basis points to 331 points. Swedish bonds closed lower, with the 10-year spread over bunds widening to 209 basis points. The Riksbank's cut in the securities repurchase rate from 7.6% to 7.4%, the seventh this year, had been expected. * Fears about the cost of BSE - so-called 'mad cow disease' - continued to overhang UK government bonds, which again underperformed other European markets. Mr Andrew Roberts at UBS said: 'There has been a real change of investor perception. BSE is the overriding factor in the market just now.' Yields on benchmark 10-year bonds rose by 5 basis points, with the yield spread over bunds, which had narrowed to 178 basis points on Monday, widening to 185 points. Yields on benchmark two-year paper closed 7 basis points higher. On Liffe, June long gilts closed at 104 7/8, down 3/8. * German bonds closed largely unchanged, with yields falling marginally on 10-year bunds and most shorter-dated paper. The market slipped in early trading, following indications from the Bundesbank that an immediate cut in short-term rates was not on the cards, but later recovered ground. On Liffe, 10-year June futures settled at 96.44, down 0.01. * French figures for household consumption in February were as expected and OATs largely tracked bunds. The 10-year yield spread widened by 2 basis points to 23 points. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1996.

headline: MARKETS - POLITICAL PRESSURES WEIGH HEAVILY ON EQUITIES - MARKET REPORT.
content: By STEVE THOMPSON, UK Stock Market editor. The political fall-out from the mad cow disease controversy continued to cast a shadow over UK equities and was said to have been responsible for another dismal performance by the stock market. With dealers increasingly taking the view that the government will struggle to recover from the political and potential economic impact of the BSE scare, gilts were persistently sold throughout the day and the Footsie future traded at a big discount to the cash market. And some of the market's bears were casting doubts about today's auction of #3bn of five-year gilts. The 10-year gilt closed off the day's low but was still 12 ticks down at the close. The 20-year gilt was 14 ticks easier. The outcome of a difficult trading session in London was that the FT-SE 100 index once again waved goodbye to the 3,700 level. By the close, it was left nursing a 21.0 fall at 3,660.9. There was much less pressure on the second-line stocks, where another outstanding performance by Securicor, a further 11% stronger following Monday's restructuring proposals, helped sustain the FT-SE Mid 250 index, which ended 2.0 off at 4,294.5. Wall Street gave precious little support to London, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average coming in on the weak side and falling sharply in the first 30 minutes of trading before staging a good rally and posting a small gain soon after that. Late in the session there was news that the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting had finished and that US interest rates had been left unchanged. Commenting on the day's events, the head trader at one of the leading UK securities houses said the institutions were worried about the political implications of the BSE scare. 'The feeling is that the government is in real trouble and that things will probably get much worse before they get better,' he said. He added that London was being propped up by Wall Street and that any big setback in New York, together with more bad news on the BSE front, could produce a nasty few days for UK stocks. Last week's burst of programme trading activity had also left the market heavy of certain stocks and caused considerable indigestion, he said. On the plus side, however, the view in the market was that the FT-SE 100 index was being depressed by a large short position in the future which, if unwound, might produce a sharp rebound. It was not all doom and gloom in the market. Glaxo Wellcome shot to the top of the FT-SE 100 leader board, in the wake of a burst of speculative buying triggered by the emergence of rumours that a merger between the company and Pfizer, of the US, could be on the cards. Most traders, although keen to take advantage of the big two-way business unleashed by the rumours, were unconvinced that such a deal was imminent. Turnover at 6pm came out at 822.8m shares, with non-FT-SE 100 stocks providing 61% of the business. Customer activity on Monday was valued at #1.59bn. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1996.

headline: MARKETS - CURRENCIES QUIET AS MARKETS WAIT ON FED MEETING - MARKETS REPORT.
content: Currency markets had a quiet day yesterday with traders mostly content to stay on the sidelines ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. The dollar closed little changed in London at DM 1.4758, from DM 1.4777, while the Fed was still meeting. Against the yen it closed at Y 106.245 from Y 106.13. The dollar firmed slightly when it emerged that the Fed had left interest rates on hold. The announcement did not come as a surprise. While many observers believe US rates will still fall further, the chance of an early cut was reduced by the freak US payrolls report last month. On the policy front, the Swedish central bank cut the repo rate to 7.4% from 7.6%, the seventh reduction of its central money market tender rate this year. In Europe the D-Mark finished slightly firmer against most currencies. The lira was the main loser, finishing at L1,064 from L1,055. Traders sold the currency after news emerged that shares in the state-controlled Banco di Napoli had been suspended. Sterling was stable, but there remain concerns that the government will pay a heavy political price for its handling of the 'mad-cow' scare. It closed at DM 2.2463, from DM 2.2536. Against the dollar it closed at $1.5222, from $1.5252. * Although the D-Mark had a slightly firmer tone yesterday, many analysts believe the outlook for the German currency is bleak. Mr Chris Turner, currency strategist at BZW in London, said 'quite a bearish story' was developing for the D-Mark. He cited three recent developments: M3 growth, the regional elections and the IFO business confidence survey. With M3 money supply growth running at six per cent year on year, Mr Turner said the necessary condition for currency depreciation - money supply growth outstripping nominal output growth - was now in place. The election result, meanwhile, said Mr Turner, 'gave Chancellor Kohl the green light to press on with EMU.' He said this was likely to be negative for the D-Mark on fears of dilution when it becomes part of a single currency. Also, with the EMU project requiring a tight fiscal policy, this would need to be countered by an environment of low interest rates. The IFO survey revealed a big drop in exporter optimism, to the lowest level since last June. Mr Turner said this was probably a lagged response to the D-Mark's large appreciation against the yen in the second half of 1995. The D-Mark has also been the subject of pessimistic comment from Robert Fleming Securities. Peter Warburton and Paul Brunker note that for 20 years the D-Mark's reputation as a dependable store of wealth 'increased in parallel with the 2.9% per annum average gain in its trade-weighted index.' Progress has been so consistent that 'it is 15 years since the D-Mark index last dropped by as much as 3% below its last year average.' But they believe there are three reasons - falling competitiveness, the role of net foreign purchases of bunds, and the issue of 'flight capital' - why the D-Mark will weaken. As evidence of the cumulative loss of competitiveness over a number of years, they note that the pace of net outflows of direct investment from Germany reached almost DM 40bn last year (roughly 40% of the size of the trade surplus), while West German employment has not recovered from the 1992 recession. Mr Brunker believes Germany is pushing for a single currency because it wants to avoid the sort of revaluation of the D-Mark, common in recent years, which took place regardless of German fundamentals. 'The feeling in Germany is that if the single currency is abolished, or even delayed, the D-Mark will go on a strong run again which the economy cannot afford.' * While the FOMC meeting held little joy for currency markets, some better news came in the form of prepared comments from Mr Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, at his confirmation hearings. 'Maintaining the key role of the dollar is important to American growth and standards of living,' he said. Repeating this comment for the second time in two weeks will remind markets that the US authorities are not indifferent to the value of the dollar. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1996.

headline: Fed spells out stance on rates decisions
content: Levels close to zero expected for 6 months Statement allows for changing conditions The Federal Reserve yesterday signalled that it still expected to keep interest rates near zero for at least six months, but for the first time identified factors that could lead to earlier rate rises. In a shift foreshadowed in the Financial Times, the US central bank tweaked guidance in its policy statement that had been unchanged since March, edging away from a simple forecast that it expects to keep rates at "exceptionally low levels" for an "extended period" - commonly understood to mean at least six months. Policymakers kept the "extended period" phrase but for the first time set out the conditions on which this guidance is based: "low rates of resource utilisation, subdued inflation trends and stable inflation expectations". The statement implies that if these conditions are not met - because of an upside surprise on growth, a pick-up in inflation or a rise in inflation expectations - the Fed may have to raise rates within the six-month period. In making this change, the US central bank spelt out what the market should watch for in terms of the factors that could lead to rate rises. Meanwhile, the Federal Open Market Committee decided to shave $25bn off the planned $200bn purchase of debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The decision was justified on technical grounds reflecting "the limited availability of agency debt". The reduction only makes the tiniest dent in the Fed's overall $1,750bn asset purchase programme. However, it was notable that the committee cut the $25bn rather than using it to buy Fannie and Freddie mortgage-backed securities. This suggests that it would take a lot to persuade mainstream Fed officials and hawks to increase the MBS purchases - an option some Fed doves want to consider. In spite of public disagreements between Fed hawks and doves in the run-up to the meeting, the statement was unanimously endorsed by the committee. This reflects the fact that there was something in it for both camps. Hawks will be able to point to the reference to "subdued inflation trends and stable inflation expectations" as indicating red lines for rate policy. Doves will say that this is obvious and changes nothing, while the reference to "resource utilisation" rather than growth highlights the importance of unemployment. If the forecast plays out as expected and the Fed's conditions are met, the Fed will not be raising rates in the next six months. But, the fact that the committee saw the need to tinker with the statement highlighted that this is far from certain.

headline: Fed sees six more months of low rates
